document.docTitle: Carotenoid profiles of red- and yellow-colored arils of cultivars of Taxus baccata L. and Taxus × media Rehder

paragraph.docTitle:
Carotenoid profiles of red- and yellow-colored arils of cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L . and
Taxus × media Rehder

document.paragraph:
Roland Schex a, b , Veronika M. Lieb c , Christian Sch¨afer a , Ralf Schweiggert b , Christof B. Steingass
b, *

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: DSM Nutritional Products, Research and Development Center Forms, P.O. Box 2676, 4002, Basel, Switzerland
Geisenheim University, Institute of Beverage Research, Analysis and Technology of Plant-based Foods, Von-Lade-Strasse 1, 65366, Germany
University of Hohenheim, Institute of Food Science and Biotechnology, Plant Foodstuff Technology and Analysis, Garbenstrasse 25, 70599, Stuttgart, Germany

document.paragraph: Dedication : Dedicated to our academic mentor Professor (em.) Dr. Dr. h.c. Reinhold Carle from the University of Hohenheim (Stuttgart, Germany ) on the occasion of his 70 th birthday.

subSection.paragraph:
Taxus baccata
L .
European yew
Identification
Quantitation
Xanthophyll ester retro -Carotenoids
Rhodoxanthin
Eschscholtzxanthin

The botanical delimitation of
Taxus species
and cultivars may be facilitated by characterizing the pigment profiles of their red- and yellow-fleshed arils. Therefore, we determined genuine carotenoid profiles of differently colored arils of seven defined cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L . and
Taxus × media Rehder.
In-depth HPLC-DAD-ESI/ APCI-MS
n
analyses revealed the presence of 43 carotenoids. Exceptional retro -carotenoids dominated the profiles of all samples assessed. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers were predominant in the red-colored arils, resulting in a rather unusual abundance of carotenoid isomers as expressed by ratios of up to 1.3:2.0:0.9 between (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin, respectively. By contrast, the uncommon yellow arils of
Taxus baccata
L . ‘Lutea’ mainly contained eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and esters. Total carotenoid concentrations ranged from 17.00 to 58.78 μg/g fresh weight across all samples assessed. Highest total rhodoxanthin concentrations of 51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fresh weight were obtained from the red arils of
Taxus × media Rehder
‘Hicksii’. Overall,
Taxus
arils represent a promising source of carotenoids and, in particular, of retro -carotenoids with exceptional molecular structures and extraordinary absorption properties.

Taxus baccata
L . ( Taxaceae ) is an evergreen conifer that belongs to the group of gymnosperms and grows best in mild oceanic climate with an annual rainfall of > 1000 L /m 2 ( Thomas and Polwart, 2003 ). The European yew (
T. baccata
) and its numerous related cultivars, e.g., ‘Elegantissima’ and ‘Washingtonii’, ubiquitously occur in the Euro-Mediterranean region ( Spjut, 2007 ). Hybrids of
Taxus sp.
are found worldwide, such as
T. × media Rehder
that originated from the hybridization of
T. baccata
and
T. cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.
( Collins et al., 2003 ).
Taxus sp.
have gained scientific publicity because of their toxic needles and seeds, representing natural sources of the taxanes baccatin III and 10-deacetylbaccatin III that are precursors of the anticancer active paclitaxel (Appendino et al., 1993; Appendino, 1995; Parmar et al., 1999 ). Yew arils, i.e., the fleshy tissue that surrounds the naked seeds, have frequently been described as edible, fleshy, and energy-rich ( Cope, 1998 ; Herrera, 1987 ). They are regularly consumed by humans either fresh or processed, e.g., in jams ( Cope, 1998 ; Pieroni, 1999 ). Although comparably low amounts of five taxane-derived compounds have been detected in arils for the first time, acute or chronic toxicity of yew arils cannot be concluded from the currently available data ( Siegle and Pietsch, 2018 ).

Fully ripe arils of
Taxus sp.
are attractive to birds owing to their mostly deep red color ( Thomas and Polwart, 2003 ), which has been attributed to the retro -carotenoid rhodoxanthin (Appendino, 1995; Kuhn and Brockmann, 1933 ). In addition, β- carotene, zeaxanthin, eschscholtzxanthin, and eschscholtzxanthone have been tentatively assigned as minor carotenoids of red-fleshed
T. baccata
arils (Bodea et al., 1964; Kuhn and Brockmann, 1933 ), although their unambiguous identification has not yet been accomplished. Moreover, the pigment profiles of unfrequently occurring yellow to golden-orange arils have remained unclear ( Spjut, 2007 ; Appendino, 1995). The retro -carotenoids eschscholtzxanthin, eschscholtzxanthone, and rhodoxanthin may be considered as compounds of particular interest due to their higher antioxidant capacity compared to that of β- carotene as reported by Maoka et al. (1996) . Moreover, rhodoxanthin has been described to be a promising pigment for conveying bright red to purple color hues to foods and beverages using techno-functional formulations prepared thereof ( Schex et al., 2020a ). The molecular structure of rhodoxanthin features an exceptionally large π- electron system of 14 conjugated double bonds, including two unusual exocyclic double bonds that have been reported to readily undergo ( E )- to ( Z )-isomerization upon dissolution in solvents and even mild thermal treatments ( Schex et al., 2020b ). In nature, abundant amounts of (6 Z )- and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin were frequently encountered in rhodoxanthin-containing plant tissues, e.g., the leaves of
Taxodium distichum
( L .) Rich. and
Cryptomeria japonica
(Thunb. ex L .f.) D.Don ( Ida et al., 1991 ) or the red-colored berries of
Lonicera sp.
( Royer et al., 2020 ). However, a comprehensive profiling of genuine carotenoids, including geometrical isomers and esters, is not yet available for differently colored arils of cultivars of
T. baccata
and related hybrids.

footnote.paragraph:
Abbreviations: APCI, atmospheric pressure chemical ionization; amu, atomic mass unit; CID, collision induced dissociation; ESI, electrospray ionization; fr. wt, fresh weight; HPLC-DAD, high performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection; MS
n
, multi-stage mass spectrometry; t BME, tert -butyl methyl ether.

subSection.paragraph:
Therefore, we present in-depth characterizations of carotenoid profiles from red- and yellow-colored arils of nine different yew trees, comprising seven defined cultivars of
T. baccata
and an interspecific hybrid
T. × media
. Carotenoids were identified and quantitated using high performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection (HPLC-DAD) and electrospray ionization (ESI) as well as atmospheric pressure chemical ionization (APCI) multi-stage mass-spectrometry (MS
n
). We sought to gain novel insights into the carotenoid profiles of yew arils, possibly facilitating the chemotaxonomic differentiation of
Taxus sp.
and cultivars and, ultimately, highlighting yew arils as promising natural source of carotenoids with high pigment concentrations.

Representative HPLC-DAD chromatograms of carotenoids from red (a) and yellow (b) arils of
Taxus sp.
and cultivars according to Table 1 are illustrated in Fig. 1 . In total, 43 carotenoids were detected in our study ( Tables 2 and 3 ). Carotenoid profiles of both red- and yellow-colored arils were dominated by retro -structured xanthophylls, i.e., (all- E )-rhodoxanthin ( 19 ), (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin ( 21 ), and various geometrical isomers derived thereof ( 5 , 6 , 8–17 , 20 ). Less abundant free carotenoids were identified as (all- E )-violaxanthin ( 1 ), (all- E )-lutein ( 2 ), (all- E )-zeaxanthin ( 3 ), and (all- E )-β- carotene ( 18 ). Moreover, esters of β- cryptoxanthin ( 22 , 23 , 26 ), lutein ( 24 , 25 , 27 , 28b , 30 ), eschscholtzxanthin ( 28a , 33 , 35 , 37–43 ), and eschscholtzxanthone ( 29 , 31 , 32 , 34 , 36 ) were assigned, having fatty acyl moieties of lauric, myristic, and palmitic acid. The genuine carotenoid profiles obtained from red- and yellow-fleshed arils unraveled a broader diversity of carotenoids within the species
T. baccata
and
T. × media
compared to that of previous studies reporting solely rhodoxanthin as the major carotenoid (Appendino, 1995; Kuhn and Brockmann, 1933 ). Eschscholtzxanthone, eschscholtzxanthin, β- carotene, and zeaxanthin have been reported as minor carotenoids of
T. baccata
arils (Bodea et al., 1964; Kuhn and Brockmann, 1933 ), although an unambiguous identification had not been achieved. We now present a detailed characterization of free and esterified carotenoids, being identified on the basis of comprehensive HPLC-DAD-ESI/APCI-MS
n
data ( Tables 2 and 3 ; Figs. 1–3 ) as described in the following.

Compounds 1 , 2 , and 3 were identified by comparing their retention times, UV/vis spectra, and mass spectral data to those of authentic reference standards ( Table 2 ). The 5,6-diepoxy carotenoid (all- E )-violaxanthin ( 1 ) was eluting first in our chromatogram, displaying molecular ions [M] +• at m/z 600 and protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 601 in the ESI positive ion mode. Collision induced dissociation (CID) in the ESI(+)-MS 2 experiment resulted in fragment ions at m/z 583 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ) and m/z 565 ([M + H – 2 H 2 O] + ) due to the loss of water. Further product ions were determined at m/z 509 ([M + H – 92] + ) and m/z 491 ([M + H – H 2 O – 92] + ), presumably upon toluene elimination of 92 atomic mass units (amu) from the polyene chain according to Steingass et al. (2020) .

Compound 2 was identified as (all- E )-lutein, showing molecular ions [M] +• at m/z 568 and, at low abundance, protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 569 in the ESI positive ion mode. An abundant in-source fragment at m/z 551 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ) was formed in the ESI(+)-MS 1 experiment, resulting from the spontaneous elimination of water at the ε- ring as reported earlier by Ziegler et al. (2015) and Schex et al. (2018). The ESI(+)-MS 2 spectrum revealed a base peak at m/z 533 ([M + H – 2 H 2 O] + ). In accordance with the literature (Schex et al., 2018; Steingass et al., 2020 ), the fragment ions detected at m/z 495 ([M + H – H 2 O – 56] + ) and m/z 429 ([M + H – H 2 O 122] + ) were attributed to retro -- Diels-Alder fragmentation of the ε- ring and cleavage of hydroxylated ε- or β- rings, respectively.

Compound 3 was unambiguously assigned to (all- E )-zeaxanthin. Molecular ions [M] +• at m/z 568 and protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 569 (both ESI(+)-MS 1 ) were detected at high abundance. In the ESI (+)-MS 2 experiment, we detected distinct fragment ions at m/z 551 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ), m/z 477 ([M + H – 92] + ), and m/z 476, being in accordance with those reported in the literature ( Schweiggert et al., 2016 ; Schex et al., 2018).

caption.paragraph:
Table 1 Characteristics of yew trees assessed, comprising cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus × media Rehder.

Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. HPLC-DAD chromatograms of carotenoids from (a) red arils of
Taxus × media Rehder
‘Hicksii’ and (b) yellow arils of
Taxus baccata
L. ‘Lutea’ at 504 (450) and 475 nm, respectively. See Tables 2 and 3 for compound assignment. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph: Compounds 12 , 16 , and 19 were the three major carotenoids in red-colored arils ( Fig. 1a ), being identified as (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-, (6 Z )-, and (all- E )- rhodoxanthin, respectively. Furthermore, six minor compounds were assigned to rhodoxanthin isomers ( 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 , 11 , 14 ) in accordance with a thermally isomerized reference standard ( Table 2 ). All rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers displayed protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 563 using ESI positive ion mode. In the ESI(+)-MS 2 experiment, the aforementioned compounds showed base peaks at m/z 359, as representatively illustrated in Fig. 2a for (all- E )-rhodoxanthin ( 19 ). Abundant product ions were detected at m/z 545 ([M + H 18] + ) and m/z 507 ([M + H 56] + ), presumably resulting from the loss of water and retro - Diels Alder fragmentation, respectively. Moreover, ESI(+)-MS 2 spectra revealed fragment ions at m/z 479 ([M + H 84] + ) that may derive from retro -Diels Alder fragmentation (56 amu) and carbon monoxide elimination (28 amu). Further distinct product ions appeared at m/z 425, 389, 281, and 209. The abundant fragment ions at m/z 425 and 359 have been previously reported for rhodoxanthin ( Cyronak et al., 1977 ). UV/vis spectra (see Table 2 and Fig. 3 ) displayed main absorption maxima ( λ max ) ranging from 478 to 502 nm across the rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers assessed, being detected at 502 nm for (all- E )-rhodoxanthin as well as at 494 and 486 nm for (6 Z )- and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin, respectively. Therefore, ( E )- to ( Z )-isomerization at the exocyclic double bonds of rhodoxanthin provoked hypsochromic shifts of 8 nm each compared to that of the (all- E )-configured molecule, being in accordance with previous reports in addition to the characteristic elution order of those rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers ( Schex et al., 2020b ). Further absorption signals were detected at 316–336 nm across the rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers assessed, resulting in a narrow range of DB/DII ratios (15–23%). Thus, no characteristic absorption bands in the near UV region, i.e., so-called ( Z )-peaks (Britton, 1995), were obtained that would have supported the tentative assignment of ( Z )-configured double bond positions at the inner polyene chain. Previously, it has been suggested on the basis of molecular modelling and steric considerations that preferred positions for the ( E/Z )-isomerization at rhodoxanthin’ s inner polyene backbone might be the C-8,9 and C-12,13 double bonds ( Schex et al., 2020b ).

In the unusual yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin ( 21 ) as well as five geometrical isomers ( 10 , 13 , 15 , 17 , 20 ) and ten esters ( 28a , 33 , 35 , 37–43 ) of eschscholtzxanthin were the prevailing pigments ( Tables 2 and 3 ; Fig. 1b ). According to Appendino (1995), pigment profiles of golden-yellow arils from special cultivars of
T. baccata
have remained unknown. Heretofore, the dihydroxy- retro -carotenoid eschscholtzxanthin has been reported to occur in the petals of
Eschscholzia californica Cham.
, the leaves of
Buxus sempervirens
L ., and the arils of
Taxus cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.
( Hormaetxe et al., 2005 ; Zhou et al., 2018 ; Maoka et al., 1996 , 2000 ). In our study, we substantiated the identification of (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ by obtaining a reference compound from the petals of
E. californica
that revealed matching retention times, UV/vis spectra, and MS data. Protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 567 were detected at low abundance for most eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers ( 10 , 15 , 17 , 20 , 21 ) in their ESI(+)-MS 1 spectra, apart from the lacking signal for one minor geometrical isomer ( 13 ). Distinct in-source fragments at m/z 549 ([M + H – H O] + ) were obtained for the 2 aforementioned peaks owing to spontaneous in-source elimination of water at C-3 (C-3 ′ ) of the ε- rings ( Fig. 2d ), by analogy to that observed for (all- E )-lutein as described above. In the ESI(+)-MS 2 experiment ( Fig. 2b ), CID of the [M + H – H O] + precursors resulted in fragment 2 ions at m/z 531 ([M + H – 2 H O] + ), m/z 457 ([M + H – H O 92] + ), 2 2 and m/z 439 ([M + H – 2 H O 92] + ) upon the loss of water and toluene 2 elimination, being in accordance with previous reports (Andrewes et al., 1979; Zhou et al., 2018 ). The abundant product ions at m/z 475 ([M + H 2 H O 56] + ) and m/z 409 ([M + H 2 H O 122] + ) may be 2 2 assigned to the loss of water and subsequent retro -Diels-Alder fragmentation or cleavage of one of the two ε- rings, respectively. UV/vis spectra of eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers (see Table 2 and Fig. 3 ) revealed three distinct maxima at 442–448 nm , 466–472 nm (main λ max ), and 494–502 nm (DIII), with the exception of one geometrical isomer ( 17 ) having a shoulder at 498 nm . For instance, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin ( 21 ) showed absorption maxima at 448, 472, and 502 nm , being in accordance with the literature (Britton, 1995). In brief, UV/vis spectra of eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers clearly differed from those of rhodoxanthin by displaying a pronounced fine structure of the absorption band, not being found for rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers ( Fig. 3 ).

Taxus baccata
L. and

B II, B II b D/Dratio of absorbance at maximum at longest wavelength (D) to D. subSection.paragraph:
In addition to the above-described free carotenoids, several xanthophyll esters were assigned in our yew arils on the basis of comprehensive HPLC-DAD-APCI-MS
n
data ( Table 3 ), comprising fatty acyl moieties of 200, 228, and 256 amu that correspond to lauric, myristic, and palmitic acid, respectively. For instance, three esters of β- cryptoxanthin ( 22 , 23 , 26 ) were identified by comparing their retention times, UV/vis spectra, and MS data to those of reference peaks obtained from an extract of papaya flesh (
Carica papaya
L .) and the respective literature ( Schweiggert et al., 2011 ). Compounds 22 , 23 , and 26 displayed protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 763 in the APCI (+)-MS 1 spectra. CID of the precursors ( m/z 763) yielded base peaks at m/z 535 ([M + H 228] + ) owing to the neutral loss of myristic acid. Further abundant product ions at m/z 671 ([M + H 92] + ), m/z 443 ([M + H – 228 92] + ), and m/z 413 ([M + H 228 122] + ) were in accordance with previous reports ( Schweiggert et al., 2016 ; Wen et al., 2017 ), resulting in the assignment of the aforementioned peaks to β- cryptoxanthin myristates. However, their geometrical isomers may not be distinguished using MS
n
fragmentation patterns. Therefore, we assigned the peaks 23 and 26 to the (all- E )- and (9 Z )-configured molecules of β- cryptoxanthin myristate, respectively, on the basis of the elution order and UV/vis spectral shape resembling those of an isomerized reference standard of free β- cryptoxanthin (data not shown).

Compounds 28a , 33 , 35 , and 37–43 were assigned to esters of eschscholtzxanthin according to their UV/vis spectra, MS data, elution order in the chromatogram ( t R ), and the disappearance of respective peaks after saponification ( Table 3 and Fig. 1b ). Compound 28a was assigned to the monoester eschscholtzxanthin myristate. In the APCI(+) mode, we detected two in-source fragments at m/z 549 ([M + H – 228] + ) and m/z 759 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ) due to the spontaneous cleavage of myristic acid and water, respectively ( Fig. 2d ). CID revealed distinct fragment ions at m/z 667 ([M + H – H 2 O 92] + ) owing to toluene elimination. Moreover, characteristic product ions of eschscholtzxanthin were detected at m/z 531, 475, 439, and 409 as described above in more detail (c.f. Tables 2 and 3 ; see also Fig. 2b and c ). Compound 33 was tentatively assigned to an isomer of eschscholtzxanthin laurate myristate according to the detection of two distinct in-source fragments at m/z 731 ([M + H 228] + ) and m/z 759 ([M + H – 200] + ) in the APCI (+)-MS 1 spectrum. By analogy to the lutein heterodiesters described above ( 25 , 30 ), we hypothesized that resonance-stabilized in-source fragments of eschscholtzxanthin monoesters have been formed upon the neutral loss of fatty acyl moieties at C-3 (C-3 ′ ) of one of the two ε- rings. However, identifying eschscholtzxanthin diesters was specifically intricate because of this spontaneous in-source elimination of fatty acids, resulting in lacking signals of molecular ions [M] • and protonated molecules [M + H] + in the APCI negative and positive ion mode, respectively. In the APCI(+)-MS 2 spectrum of compound 33 , two respective product ions at m/z 639 ([M + H 228 92] + ) and m/z 667 ([M + H – 200 92] + ) appeared owing to the elimination of toluene and, therefore, further substantiated its identification as laurate myristate diester of eschscholtzxanthin. As a consequence of their elution after peak 33 ( t R = 14.9 min), compounds 35 and 37–43 ( t R ≥ 14.9 min) were also classified as diesters of eschscholtzxanthin. For the two most abundant eschscholtzxanthin diesters ( 39 , 42 ), single in-source fragments at m/z 759 (M + H 228) were detected in the APCI(+)-MS 1 spectra. Moreover, CID yielded typical fragment ions at m/z 667 ([M + H 228 92] + ) due to toluene elimination. Therefore, both compounds ( 39 , 42 ) were tentatively assigned to ( E/Z )-isomers of eschscholtzxanthin dimyristate.

subSection.paragraph: Five eschscholtzxanthone esters ( 29 , 31 , 32 , 34 , 36 ) were identified in the red-colored arils ( Table 3 and Fig. 1a ). In the APCI(+)-MS 1 experiment, in-source fragments at m/z 547 ([M + H fatty acid] + ) were detected at high abundance for all eschscholtzxanthone esters owing to the spontaneous in-source elimination of fatty acids as described above for eschscholtzxanthin esters. In addition, APCI()-MS 1 experiments yielded signals at m/z 773 ([M H]) and m/z 774 ([M] • ) for the compounds 32 and 34 , thus being assigned to ( E/Z )-isomers of eschscholtzxanthone myristate. Even though no distinct signals of the molecular ions were detected, compounds 29 , 31 , and 36 were also classified as esters of eschscholtzxanthone on the basis of their presence before and absence after sample saponification. APCI(+)-MS 2 experiments of the compounds 29 , 31 , 32 , 34 , and 36 revealed fragment ions at m/z 491 ([M + H fatty acid 56] + ) and m/z 455 ([M + H fatty acid 92] + ) due to retro -Diels-Alder fragmentation of the ε- ring and toluene elimination, respectively. Noteworthy, product ions at m/z 463 ([M + H fatty acid 84]) + , possibly deriving from the fragmentation of the ε- ring carrying the oxo-group, were detected as observed during CID of rhodoxanthin. UV/vis spectra of the assigned eschscholtzxanthone esters did not exhibit a pronounced fine structure but rather single maxima ranging from 478 to 486 nm (see Table 3 and Fig. 3 ), being a characteristic feature of carotenoids with conjugated oxo-groups in the molecular structure according to Chac´on-Ordo´˜nez et al. (2017) and Britton (1995).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. UV/vis absorption spectra of (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin (solid line), (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthone (dashed line), and (all- E )-rhodoxanthin (dot-dashed line) at 210–700 nm from the arils of cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus × media Rehder.

Fig. 2. ESI(+)-MS 2 spectra of the compounds 19 and 21 from the arils of cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus × media Rehder
assigned to (all- E )- rhodoxanthin (a) and (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin (b), respectively. Proposed mass fragmentation of eschscholtzxanthin (c) and the formation of resonancestabilized in-source fragments as shown for eschscholtzxanthin and eschscholtzxanthin myristate (d) ( Ziegler et al., 2015 ; Breithaupt et al., 2002; Enzell and Back, 1995 ).

subSection.paragraph:
Carotenoid concentrations in μg/g fresh weight (fr. wt) of red- and yellow-colored arils of various defined cultivars of
T. baccata
and the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
are compiled in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively. Overall, the hitherto unprecedented quantitation of carotenoids in yew arils revealed total concentrations of 17.00–58.78 μg/g fr. wt across all samples assessed. According to Britton and Khachik (2009), the aforementioned concentrations classify as high (5–20 μg/g fr. wt) to very high ( > 20 μg/g fr. wt). Carotenoid concentrations of our yew arils were in the range of those reported earlier for various tropical crops, e.g., peach palm fruits (6.9–138.95 μg/g fr. wt), mamey sapote (37.86–80.76 μg/g fr. wt), and cashew apples (6.93–52.78 μg/g fr. wt) with differently colored flesh and peel ( Schweiggert et al., 2016 ; Hempel et al., 2014 ; Chacon-Ord´o´nez ˜et al., 2017). Furthermore, yew arils of our study exhibited higher carotenoid concentrations than those found in several other carotenoid-rich fruits and vegetables like pineapple and sweet potato, being previously reported to contain 0.29–5.65 and 2.4–24.6 μg/g fr. wt, respectively ( Steingass et al., 2020 ; Drapal and Fraser, 2019 ). Therefore, we characterized the arils of
T. baccata
and
T. × media
as rich source of carotenoids that is widely distributed in the Euro-Mediterranean region.

Genuine carotenoid profiles of all red-colored arils were clearly dominated by rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers, accumulating to a sum of 19.46–51.33 μg/g fr. wt ( Table 4 ) and, therefore, representing a rhodoxanthin source with high to very high concentrations (Britton and Khachik, 2009). Rhodoxanthin accounted for strikingly high 87–99% of the total carotenoids across all red samples. Red arils of
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fr. wt) were characterized by significantly higher total rhodoxanthin concentrations than those of aril samples obtained from cultivars of
T. baccata
. (all- E )-Rhodoxanthin prevailed in the arils of
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ and
T. baccata
‘Elegantissima’, whereas (6 Z )-rhodoxanthin was the most abundant ( E/Z )-isomer of red arils from the remaining cultivars. On the basis of their mean values, (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin were determined to be deposited in ratios ranging from 2.1:2.0:0.7 (
T. × media
‘Hicksii’,
T. baccata
‘Elegantissima’) to 1.3:2.0:0.9 (
T. baccata
1). Therefore, our study revealed that rhodoxanthin isomers with ( Z )-configured exocyclic double bonds abundantly occurred in yew arils, resulting in similar ratios of 2:2:1 to 1:2:1 between (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin as found earlier in the leaves of several gymnosperms ( Ida et al., 1991 ), the bird plumage of
Ilicura militaris ( Hudon et al., 2007 )
, and the red-colored berries of
Lonicera sp.
( Royer et al., 2020 ). Nevertheless, in yew arils we did not observe ratios of up to 1:2:2 as reported previously for the thermally induced ( E/Z )-isomer equilibria of dissolved rhodoxanthin at 50–70 ◦ C ( Schex et al., 2020b ). In future studies, carotenoid profiling of yew arils at earlier maturity stages may further elucidate the evolution of ratios between geometrical ( E/Z )-isomers of rhodoxanthin.

caption.paragraph:
Carotenoid concentrations (μg/g fresh weight) of red-colored arils of cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus × media Rehder.

tableNote.paragraph: Values represent mean ± standard deviation. Significant differences ( p ≤ 0.05) within a row are indicated by different letters.
a Calculated as sum of rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and eschscholtzxanthone esters.

subSection.paragraph:
Eschscholtzxanthone esters further contributed to the high concentration of retro -carotenoids in all red-colored samples assessed, in total amounting to 19.48–54.46 μg/g fr. wt. The highest concentration of eschscholtzxanthone esters was obtained from
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (3.12 ± 0.18 μg/g fr. wt) as well as
T. baccata
‘Hessei’ (1.72 ± 0.04 μg/g fr. wt) and ‘Washingtonii’ (1.31 ± 0.01 μg/g fr. wt). Furthermore, significantly higher levels of (all- E )-β- cryptoxanthin myristate were determined in
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (2.94 ± 0.05 μg/g fr. wt) and
T. baccata
‘Hessei’ (2.55 ± 0.11 μg/g fr. wt) compared to those found in all other red-colored yew arils. Noteworthy, the cultivar ‘Dovastonii Aurea’ showed the lowest total carotenoid concentration (20.33 ± 0.51 μg/g fr. wt) but a significantly higher quantity of (all- E )-lutein (0.56 ± 0.06 μg/g fr. wt) than those of the remaining red aril samples (0.17–0.25 μg/g fr. wt). In brief, carotenoid concentrations of red-colored arils differed remarkably between the cultivars of
Taxus sp.
assessed in our study, in particular, those of the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
‘Hicksii’.

Yellow-colored arils of the cultivar
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ were characterized by a clearly differing carotenoid profile compared to those of
Taxus sp.
and cultivars bearing red-colored arils, resulting in a distinctive morphological differentiating factor, i.e., the visual color appearance of yew arils ( c.f. arils in Fig. 1a and b ). Total carotenoid concentrations of yellow arils ranged from 17.00 ± 0.52 to 19.55 ± 1.00 μg/g fr. wt, thus being significantly lower than those of red-colored arils with
T. baccata ‘Dovastonii
Aurea’ (20.33 ± 0.51 μg/g fr. wt) being the exception. The latter showed that the apparent color difference between yellow- and red-colored arils may be primarily assigned to the carotenoid profiles rather than the total carotenoid concentration. In particular, when considering the bathochromic shifts of the UV/vis absorption spectra owing to stepwise dehydration of the hydroxy groups of eschscholtzxanthin (yellow arils) to eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin (red arils) and the resulting prolongation of the chromophore by up to two oxo-groups ( Fig. 3 ).

In the yellow-colored arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’, eschscholtzxanthin amounted in total to 14.83–17.36 μg/g fr. wt and, thus, accounted for 87–89% of the total carotenoids. So far, eschscholtzxanthin has been reported to be predominant in the petals of California poppy (
E. californica
) with 32% of the total carotenoids ( Zhou et al., 2018 ). Free, i.e., non-esterified, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin prevailed in our yellow-colored arils with concentrations of 5.73 ± 0.31 and 8.14 ± 0.41 μg/g fr. wt. Moreover, yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ abundantly contained eschscholtzxanthin isomers (2.58–2.61 μg/g fr. wt) and esters (6.49–6.64 μg/g fr. wt). In previous reports on
E. californica
, biosynthetic pathways to eschscholtzxanthin have been proposed via zeaxanthin, antheraxanthin, and a trihydroxy- retro -carotenoid ( Maoka et al., 2000 ; Zhou et al., 2018 ). (all- E )-Zeaxanthin was quantitated in our yellow-colored arils in small amounts (0.09–0.30 μg/g fr. wt), whereas antheraxanthin and the aforementioned trihydroxy- retro -carotenoid were not detected as compared to an authentic reference standard and the extract from petals of
E. californica
, respectively. However, the presence of such biosynthetic precursors of eschscholtzxanthin in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ cannot be excluded on the basis of the available data and might be elucidated by carotenoid profiling of aril samples at earlier maturity stages. By contrast, it was clearly shown that retro -carotenoids featuring oxo-groups in their molecular structure, e.g., eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin, were not detected in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ (see section 2.1). Therefore, we hypothesized by reverse analogy, that rhodoxanthin synthase is either missing or apparently showing insufficient activity in the arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. Hence, the tentative biosynthetic pathway from eschscholtzxanthin to eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin might be hampered in yellow-colored arils. This major difference in the carotenoid profile of our yew arils resulted in colors ranging from yellow and golden-orange for arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ to bright red for those of the remaining yew trees assessed.

Light micrographs of fresh aril tissue of
T. baccata
‘Hessei’ and ‘Lutea’ both revealed cluster of small and round-shaped chromoplasts of red and yellow color, respectively (c.f. Fig. 4a and b ). The shapes of the chromoplasts of both red and yellow-colored yew arils were similar to those of mamey sapote pulp and goji berries (Chacon-Ord´o´nez ˜et al., 2016; Hempel et al., 2017 ), whereas elongated, needle-shaped, crystalline carotenoid structures were not observed as typically found in tomatoes and carrots ( Schweiggert et al., 2012 ). However, chromoplasts of yellow arils from
T. baccata
‘Lutea’, predominantly containing ( E/Z )-isomers and esters of eschscholtzxanthin instead of oxo- retro -carotenoids like rhodoxanthin, appeared to be very luminescent using polarized light, while chromoplasts of red-fleshed arils did not show this phenomenon. These findings indicate that the respective carotenoids in yellow yew arils were deposited in the aril tissue in a highly ordered or even crystalline state. This highly ordered form might comprise H-type aggregates that have been reported earlier for other dihydroxy-carotenoids like lutein and zeaxanthin, but might also comprise J-type aggregates as have been reported for xanthophyll esters ( Hempel et al., 2016 ). By contrast, polarized light microscopy revealed that the carotenoids present in the chromoplasts of our red-colored arils, i.e., mostly containing ( E/Z )-isomers of rhodoxanthin and eschscholtzxanthone esters, were deposited presumably in a non-ordered or low-ordered state. In fundamental studies on the aggregation of rhodoxanthin, isomers with ( Z )-configured double bonds at the inner polyene backbone have been reported to hamper aggregation at abundances of > 3% ( Schex et al., 2020a ). In our red-colored arils, those rhodoxanthin isomers ( 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 , 11 , 14 ) contributed to 6–15% of the total rhodoxanthin concentration and, therefore, their presence might explain the lacking luminescence of red chromoplasts under polarized light. However, further study is warranted because the currently available knowledge on deposition forms or aggregate types of retro --carotenoids like rhodoxanthin, eschscholtzxanthone, and eschscholtzxanthin is very scarce, in particular, in plant tissues.

caption.paragraph:
Carotenoid concentrations (μg/g fresh weight) of yellow-colored arils of
Taxus baccata
L. ‘Lutea’.

subSection.paragraph:
Our study reports an in-depth carotenoid profiling of red- and yellow-colored arils of defined cultivars of two
Taxus sp.
, i.e.,
T. baccata
and the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
. Carotenoid profiles of yew arils were dominated by exceptional retro -carotenoids. In red-fleshed arils, we assigned nine rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and five eschscholtzxanthone esters. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers amounted to a maximum of 51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fr. wt, being predominantly represented by (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin in different ratios. By contrast, ( E/Z )- isomers and esters of eschscholtzxanthin were the major pigments in the yellow-fleshed arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. The high total carotenoid concentrations of 17.00–58.78 μg/g fr. wt across all samples assessed may support valorizing yew arils as promising source of carotenoids and, in particular, of retro -carotenoids with exceptional molecular structures and extraordinary absorption properties. Although arils of
Taxus sp.
have historically been consumed by humans, non-toxicity and, thus, safety of yew aril consumption needs to be ensured prior to define efficient downstream processing for obtaining natural carotenoid extracts from yew arils. Further insights into the ultrastructure of yew aril plastids and the deposition of carotenoids might be elucidated in continuative studies using transmission electron microscopy and in vitro digestion models as established previously for other plant tissues ( Hempel et al., 2017 ; Chac´on-Ordo´nez ˜et al., 2016). Moreover, chemotaxonomic chromoplast characterization beyond carotenoid profiles might be used as additional marker to substantiate the differentiation of
Taxus sp.
as has been reported by Collins et al. (2003) on the basis of e.g., chloroplast genotyping and fingerprinting of deoxyribonucleic acid.

tableNote.paragraph: Values represent mean ± standard deviation. Significant differences ( p ≤ 0.05) within a row are indicated by different letters.
a Calculated as sum of ( E/Z )-isomers and esters of eschscholtzxanthin.
b Calculated as sum of esters of lutein and eschscholtzxanthin.

subSection.paragraph: Diethyl ether, ethyl acetate, n -hexane, methanol, tert -butyl methyl ether ( t BME), and potassium hydroxide were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany ). Butylated hydroxytoluene and calcium carbonate were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Taufkirchen, Germany ) and Fluka Chemie (Buchs, Switzerland ), respectively. All chemicals were at least of HPLC or analytical grade. Purified water (PURELAB Ultra, ELGA LabWater, High Wycombe, United Kingdom ; Milli-Q Gradient, Merck) was used throughout the experiments.

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Arils of cultivars of Taxus baccata L. and

document.paragraph:
In November 2018 , arils were harvested from the yew tree collection planted in the Hohenheim Gardens (Stuttgart, Germany ). Red-colored arils were collected from two
Taxus baccata
L. ( Taxaceae ) yew trees and four defined cultivars, i.e., ‘Dovastonii Aurea’, ‘Washingtonii’, ‘Elegantissima’, and ‘Hessei’. The sampling further comprised red-fleshed arils of the interspecific hybrid
Taxus × media Rehder
‘Hicksii’ ( Taxaceae ). Yellow-colored arils were harvested from two yew trees of the cultivar
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. Planting years and GPS coordinates of sample specimens are listed in Table 1 as available online in the information system on plants of the Hohenheim Gardens ( University of Hohenheim, 2019 ). Three individual samples ( n = 3) consisting of at least 10 arils were collected from each yew tree. Arils were frozen after harvest using liquid nitrogen, vacuum-sealed in laminated foil, and stored at 20 ◦ C until carotenoid extraction.

heading.emphasis: 4.5. Carotenoid identification by HPLC-DAD-ESI/APCI-MS n analyses

subSection.paragraph: For compound identification, we pooled several extracts of red- and yellow-colored arils, respectively. In case that saponification was deemed appropriate, we followed the protocol as reported by Schex et al. (2018). Briefly, the dried extracts were re-dissolved in 2 mL diethyl ether and 2 mL methanolic potassium hydroxide (10%, w/v ), flushed with nitrogen, and saponified for 3 h under continuous stirring and light exclusion. After washing the saponified extracts twice with 2 mL water, the organic phases were collected, evaporated to dryness using a gentle nitrogen stream, and re-dissolved for HPLC analyses as described in section 4.4.

A Thermo Fisher Accela HPLC series was equipped with a diode array detector and coupled to a LXQ mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, San Jose, CA, USA ). The injection volume was 20 μL. Carotenoids were chromatographically separated at 23 ◦ C on a C 30 reversed phase column (150 × 3.0 mm i.d., 3 μ m particle size, YMC Europe, Dinslaken, Germany ) protected by a YMC guard cartridge of the same material. HPLC eluents were mixtures of methanol/ t BME/water (eluent A, 90:8:2, v / v / v ; eluent B, 20:78:2, v / v / v ). Following elution gradient was applied at a constant flow rate of 0.5 mL/min: Isocratic at 100% A (1 min), 100% to 0% A (12 min), isocratic hold at 0% A (3 min), 0% to 100% A (0.1 min), isocratic at 100% A (4.9 min). Total run time was 21 min. UV/vis absorption spectra were recorded at 270–800 nm . Ratios of DIII/DII (%) and DB/DII (%) were determined according to Britton (1995).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. Light micrographs of (a) red arils of
Taxus baccata
L. ‘Hessei’ and (b) yellow arils of
Taxus baccata
L. ‘Lutea’. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
For MS
n
analyses of free carotenoids, the aforementioned HPLC-MS system was equipped with an ESI source, operating in positive ion mode at a scan range of m/z 150–1500 for MS 1 spectra. Nitrogen was used as sheath, auxiliary, and sweep gas at flow rates of 40, 5, and 5 arbitrary units, respectively. Further settings were as follows: Spray voltage, 5000 V; capillary temperature, 300 ◦ C ; capillary voltage, 6.0 V; tube lens, 45 V. CID was achieved by applying a normalized collision energy of 35% and an isolation width of m/z 3.

MS
n
analyses of xanthophyll esters were performed using an APCI source in negative and positive ion mode, a MS 1 scan range of m/z 300–1500, and the sheath, auxiliary, and sweep gas at the aforementioned conditions. Further settings: Vaporizer temperature, 350 ◦ C ; discharge current, 5 μA; capillary temperature, 300 ◦ C ; capillary voltage, 6.0 V; tube lens, 45 V; normalized collision energy (CID), 35%; isolation width, m/z 3. Xcalibur software (version 2.0.7 SP1) was used for data acquisition (Thermo Fisher Scientific).

Light micrographs were taken using an Axioskop microscope (Zeiss, Feldbach, Germany ) equipped with an Axiocam 105 color camera (Zeiss, Gottingen ¨, Germany ). Fresh, freehand tissue samples of red (
T. baccata
L . ‘Hessei’) and yellow (
T. baccata
L . ‘Lutea’) arils were assessed using bright field and phase contrast. Polarized light was used to characterize the deposition of carotenoids in the chromoplasts.

Compounds were assigned by comparing their retention times ( t R ), UV/vis absorption spectra, and mass spectra to those of authentic reference standards and thermally isomerized samples derived thereof. Moreover, spectral data was compared to the literature.

The extraction work-up was conducted under reduced light exposure to inhibit carotenoid isomerization and degradation. The frozen arils were separated manually from the seeds and homogenized using a Polytron PT 1300 D disperser (Kinematica, Lucerne , Switzerland ) at 15 000 rpm for 2.5 min. Each aril puree was analyzed in duplicate. Aliquots of 320 ± 40 mg and ca. 50 mg calcium carbonate were mixed with 2 mL of a mixture of methanol/ethyl acetate/ n -hexane (1:1:1, v/v/v ) containing 0.2 g /L butylated hydroxytoluene as antioxidant. Carotenoids were extracted for 10 min in an ice-cooled ultrasonic bath. After adding 1 mL water, samples were centrifuged and the organic phases were collected. The remainders were re-extracted 2–3 times using 1 mL of the aforementioned extraction solvent in the ultrasonic bath for 5 min. Organic phases were collected, evaporated to dryness using a gentle nitrogen stream, and stored at 20 ◦ C until further analyses. For HPLC analyses, dried extracts were re-dissolved in t BME/methanol (1:1, v/v ), membrane-filtered (polytetrafluoroethylene, 0.45 μm, Pall Life Sciences, Ann Arbor, MI, USA ), and filled into amber glass vials.

Carotenoids were extracted as described in section 4.4 and quantitated using an Agilent series 1100 HPLC system coupled to a G1315A DAD (Agilent, Waldbronn, Germany ) and the above-described chromatographic conditions. The injection volume was 10 μL. Linear calibration curves of (all- E )-β- carotene ( 0.03–31.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99998), ( E/Z )-rhodoxanthin ( 0.05–13.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99987), and (all- E )-zeaxanthin ( 0.04–13.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99995) were used for quantitation. Stock solution concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically using molar extinction coefficients as reported by Britton (1995). A scan range of 210–700 nm was used to record UV/vis spectra. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers were monitored at 488, 496, and 504 nm . Eschscholtzxanthone esters were detected at 475 and 488 nm , being quantitated using the rhodoxanthin calibration. Eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and the respective esters were detected at 465 and 475 nm . All other carotenoids including their esters were monitored at 450 nm . β- Cryptoxanthin, eschscholtzxanthin, lutein, and violaxanthin as well as respective geometrical isomers and esters were quantitated using the calibration curve of (all- E )-zeaxanthin. Molecular weight correction factors were applied if necessary. Esters were quantitated as equivalent of the respective free carotenoid.

Univariate statistical analyses were performed using Minitab 18 (State College, PA, USA ). Normality and homogeneity of variances of data sets were evaluated by Ryan-Joiner’ s ( p ≤ 0.05) and Levene’ s test ( p ≤ 0.05), respectively. Tukey’ s test ( p ≤ 0.05) was applied to determine significant differences between data showing normal distribution and homogenous variances. Data sets without normal distribution were applied to the Kruskal-Wallis test ( p ≤ 0.05).

The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests: R. Schex and C . Sch¨afer work for a commercial manufacturer of carotenoids (DSM Nutritional Products).

subSection.paragraph: Schex, R., Lieb, V.M., Jim´enez, V.M., Esquivel, P., Schweiggert, R.M., Carle, R.,

paragraph.bibRef:
